evidence.quote: For the purposes of cyber attribution, our focus is from that of cyber security.
evidence.paraphrase: The thesis limits the concept of 'cyber' for attribution work to a cyber-security perspective, i.e. attributes relevant to security analysts.
evidence.researcher_comment: This statement narrows the project's scope to cyber‑security use cases, which clarifies which attributes will be prioritised. It excludes broader socio-technical interpretations of 'cyber' and will shape library/feature selection. Analysts should note this when mapping findings to other research questions outside security-focused attribution.

evidence.quote: for the purpose of this thesis it was decided that cyber was information based.
evidence.paraphrase: The thesis defines 'cyber' as information‑based, i.e. focused on digital information (data and metadata) for attribution purposes.
evidence.researcher_comment: Explicitly framing 'cyber' as information-based steers attribute collection toward digital artefacts and metadata rather than non-digital context. This decision helps bound the framework but may omit non-digital signals that could be relevant in some attribution cases.

evidence.quote: Although this phrase was originally used as a slang term for the internet its official dictionary definition is ”a realm of electronic communication”.
evidence.paraphrase: The document adopts the dictionary meaning of 'cyber space' as 'a realm of electronic communication', covering any medium that transmits or stores digital information.
evidence.researcher_comment: A purposely broad, medium‑agnostic definition that permits inclusion of RF, wired, and other channels in attribution libraries. The breadth aids extensibility but may increase heterogeneity of attributes to manage.

evidence.quote: Cyber Security therefore relates to any action that is required to keep the information safe and available.
evidence.paraphrase: Cyber security is defined as actions taken to keep information safe and available (i.e., preservation of CIA properties) for attribution and defence.
evidence.researcher_comment: Tying security to information availability/safety focuses attribution on evidence that affects confidentiality, integrity, and availability. The definition also explicitly allows physical attacks on equipment to be considered under 'cyber security'.

evidence.quote: Ultimately it is the search for characteristics which can be associated with an attack or an individual.
evidence.paraphrase: The thesis frames cyber attribution as the identification of characteristics that can be associated with an attack or an individual actor.
evidence.researcher_comment: This operational definition justifies building attribute libraries and a taxonomy of features. It is intentionally broad — 'characteristics' must be disambiguated into concrete, testable attributes (which the thesis attempts via libraries).

evidence.quote: The ultimate goal of traceback attribution is to follow the communications back to the original source, usually in the form of an IP address.
evidence.paraphrase: Traceback attribution aims to trace communications back to their origin, typically identified as an IP address.
evidence.researcher_comment: This sets expectations for what traceback can provide but the thesis elsewhere notes practical obstacles (spoofing, proxies, non-cooperative networks). The definition is network-centric and may understate challenges in attributing persons rather than devices.

evidence.quote: Full attribution is when a specific action can be assigned to an individual person.
evidence.paraphrase: Full attribution is defined as assigning a specific cyber action to a named individual, the level required for legal proceedings.
evidence.researcher_comment: This distinguishes levels of attribution and highlights that 'full attribution' carries much higher evidentiary burdens than device- or traceback-level attribution. It signals the need for rigorous evidentiary standards for legal use.

evidence.quote: At the conclusion of the project there is a proposed framework for the use of analysts working on the attribution problem.
evidence.paraphrase: The project's principal output is a proposed analyst-oriented cyber attribution framework.
evidence.researcher_comment: This is the central deliverable claimed by the thesis; subsequent text summarises validation experiments but further external validation and peer replication are needed to judge generalisability. The claim is descriptive of output rather than evaluative.

evidence.quote: It was shown to be suitable for multidisciplinary work through the inclusion of linguistic and RF libraries.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors report the framework is suitable for multidisciplinary collaboration by incorporating linguistic and radio‑frequency libraries.
evidence.researcher_comment: Empirical support is limited to those two library domains; while encouraging, this result does not prove generalisability across other disciplines. Integration and semantic-mapping challenges between domains remain an implementation risk.

evidence.quote: This was an especially pleasing demonstration of the framework as an information sharing platform as a colleague without any prior training was able to use the framework to extract the relevant information.
evidence.paraphrase: In a live demonstration, an untrained colleague was able to use the framework to extract relevant attribution information, showing usability for information sharing.
evidence.researcher_comment: Anecdotal usability evidence is positive but limited (single demonstration). Systematic usability testing and metrics (time, error rates) are needed to substantiate the claim at scale.

evidence.quote: The ultimate goal of the project is to create a framework suitable for the sharing of attribution data between technical specialists.
evidence.paraphrase: Methodologically, the study sets out to build a shared attribution-data framework to enable exchange between technical specialists.
evidence.researcher_comment: This objective drives design choices (library format, attribute tuples, confidence values). It implicitly assumes cross-team cooperation and compatible data semantics — a socio-technical challenge that requires governance and standards.

evidence.quote: The framework must be robust enough to enable expansion as technologies develop, however accurate enough to be useful to analysts in todays attribution problem.
evidence.paraphrase: Design requirement: the framework must be extensible for future technologies while remaining accurate and practical for analysts today.
evidence.researcher_comment: This highlights a core trade-off (extensibility vs. precision) and motivates the chosen mathematical/confidence modelling. Implementers will need validation metrics and governance to balance extensibility with analytic reliability.

evidence.quote: The model is not design for strategic analysis.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors explicitly state the model is not intended for strategic‑level attribution analysis.
evidence.researcher_comment: This limitation confines the framework to tactical/operational use; it should not be used directly for national-level or political attribution without integration with higher-level models. Users must avoid over-extending conclusions beyond scope.

evidence.quote: There is a concern that with too many libraries the framework would become too cumbersome and a great level of knowledge would be required in order to use it.
evidence.paraphrase: The thesis warns that proliferation of libraries could make the system cumbersome and require significant user expertise to operate.
evidence.researcher_comment: This identifies an operational scalability and usability risk; it implies the need for library governance, discovery/search, and UX strategies (or role-based views) to keep the system practical for analysts.

evidence.quote: A lot of time was wasted during the project developing libraries that ultimately were incompatible or out of date.
evidence.paraphrase: The project experienced significant time loss creating libraries that became incompatible or obsolete, revealing maintenance challenges.
evidence.researcher_comment: This operational lesson signals a need for versioning, lifecycle management, and standards for library creation. It weakens reproducibility unless addressed by process improvements.

evidence.quote: From the experimentation it has been found that the framework could be improved through the highlighting of new information as it is being populated.
evidence.paraphrase: They recommend adding an interface feature to highlight newly added information during live population of the framework.
evidence.researcher_comment: A low-cost, actionable UX improvement that likely enhances analyst situational awareness in fast-time investigations. Should be implemented and validated with time-to-detection/user-satisfaction metrics.

evidence.quote: Proposed libraries would include, but are not limited to; - HTML - Scripting languages - Social Media - IPV6 - Bluetooth
evidence.paraphrase: The authors propose expanding the library set to include HTML, scripting languages, social media, IPv6 and Bluetooth libraries.
evidence.researcher_comment: This list mixes application-layer (HTML, social media) and protocol/physical-layer (IPv6, Bluetooth) targets; each has distinct collection, legal and feature-selection challenges that must be scoped separately.

evidence.quote: Powershell, Python and Ruby should be prioritised due to their extensive use in cyber attacks.
evidence.paraphrase: They recommend prioritising PowerShell, Python and Ruby libraries because these scripting languages are heavily used in cyber attacks.
evidence.researcher_comment: Prioritising these scripting languages aligns with operational threat patterns and should yield high impact for attribution. Implementation is feasible because these languages expose rich, author-specific artefacts (e.g., scripting idioms, module use).

evidence.quote: An obvious library that is missing is for IP Version 6.
evidence.paraphrase: The authors identify IPv6 support as a missing library to be added in future work.
evidence.researcher_comment: IPv6 adoption is growing; omitting IPv6 limits future applicability. IPv6 carries different header fields and extension headers that could provide new attribution signals, so this is a high-priority gap.

evidence.quote: adopt a widely recognised data exchange format such as STIX *Barnum (2012)*.
evidence.paraphrase: They recommend adopting a standard threat‑intelligence exchange format (STIX) to improve interoperability and adoption.
evidence.researcher_comment: Integrating STIX would aid interoperability with other CTI tools but requires a careful mapping from the framework's attribute model to STIX structures. This is non-trivial and needs an explicit schema/mapping effort.
